headers.access-control-expose-headers: ETag, Link, Location, Retry-After, X-GitHub-OTP, X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Used, X-RateLimit-Resource, X-RateLimit-Reset, X-OAuth-Scopes, X-Accepted-OAuth-Scopes, X-Poll-Interval, X-GitHub-Media-Type, X-GitHub-SSO, X-GitHub-Request-Id, Deprecation, Sunset

nodes.body:
+1 for this change.

I personally don’t think nested handoffs are better, for a few reasons:

* It is incompatible with server-managed conversation. #2151
* It break prompt caching by default.
* More importantly, it makes context engineering much harder. Many context editing techniques rely on item-level structure: keep only the last N turns, drop old tool outputs, trim specific ranges, etc. When `nest_handoff_history` collapses everything into one long string, those techniques become hard (or impossible) to apply.

So, I think nested handoffs should be an opt-in “context editing feature" at handoff time. And I think we can have multiple strategies to choose from in the future. For example, the new Responses API `compact` looks promising. It would be great if it could be offered as one option. More broadly, it may be worth designing a generic context editing interface or middleware so different strategies can be plugged in, and applied at different points, not only during handoff. For example, it could run between turns as well.
